evals.prompt: I want to write an article about how remote work has changed team communication. I have a few main points: async communication has largely replaced real-time meetings, tools like Slack have created new social norms, and managers need to adapt their leadership style.
evals.expected_output: The orchestrator correctly detects Stage 1 (clear topic + initial thoughts), invokes article-style-selector, and shows a progress bar with Structure as the active stage.
expectations: The orchestrator identifies this as a Stage 1 entry point (user has a clear topic and initial thoughts)
The orchestrator invokes the article-style-selector agent
The response includes a progress bar or stage indicator showing Structure as the active/current stage
The orchestrator does NOT just write the article itself — it delegates to the appropriate agent
The orchestrator asks the user for confirmation or presents a summary before proceeding further

evals.prompt: I want to write something about AI but I'm really not sure what angle to take. There's so much to say but I can't quite articulate what I actually want to explore.
evals.expected_output: The orchestrator detects Stage 0 (vague idea, no clear direction), invokes the socratic-ideation-partner agent to help clarify the idea.
expectations: The orchestrator identifies this as a Stage 0 entry point (vague idea, user can't articulate their angle)
The orchestrator invokes the socratic-ideation-partner agent
The orchestrator explains that it will help the user refine and clarify their idea before structuring the article
The orchestrator does NOT jump straight to article-style-selector or article-drafter

evals.prompt:
Here's my finished draft that I'd like help editing and polishing:

---
Title: The Hidden Cost of Convenience

We live in an age of unprecedented convenience. With a few taps on a smartphone, we can summon food, transportation, or entertainment in minutes. But as these systems have grown more seamless, something quieter has happened beneath the surface: we have gradually outsourced our discomfort.

The problem isn't convenience itself. It's that convenience, in its current form, often functions as an avoidance mechanism. When we can skip any moment of friction — the wait, the walk, the conversation — we begin to lose our tolerance for difficulty. And with that tolerance goes something harder to name: the capacity to sit with a problem long enough to actually solve it.

This essay argues that the real cost of convenience culture is not laziness, but a shrinking threshold for difficulty — and that recovering it requires deliberate friction.
---
evals.expected_output: The orchestrator detects Stage 3 (completed draft), invokes the article-editor agent, and shows a progress bar with Editing as the active stage.
expectations: The orchestrator identifies this as a Stage 3 entry point (user has a completed draft)
The orchestrator invokes the article-editor agent
The response includes a progress bar or stage indicator showing Editing as the active/current stage
The orchestrator does NOT re-run ideation or structure stages since the user already has a draft
The orchestrator passes the full draft content to the article-editor agent
